thread.section_title: National News -  New York Daily News
thread.title: President Trump tells Israel to halt settlement construction
thread.title_full: President Trump tells Israel to halt settlement construction

author: CHRIS SOMMERFELDT
title: President Trump tells Israel to halt settlement construction
text:
President Trump tells Israel to halt settlement construction on Palestinian land President Trump tells Israel to halt settlement construction Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced plans for 2,000 new settlement homes Thursday. (JACK GUEZ/AFP/Getty Images) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated: Thursday, February 2, 2017, 9:42 PM 
President Trump, who campaigned on an unapologetically pro-Israel platform, has told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to halt construction of settlements on occupied Palestinian land â€” just hours after the Israeli leader rolled out plans for 2,000 new settlement homes. 
"While we don't believe the existence of settlements is an impediment to peace, the construction of new settlements or the expansion of existing settlements beyond their current borders may not be helpful in achieving that goal," the White House said in a statement. 
The statement noted that the Trump administration has yet to take an official stance on "settlement activity," and that the issue will be discussed when the President sits down with Netanyahu in Washington, D.C. on Feb. 15. The issue will be further discussed when President Trump sits down with Netanyahu in Washington, D.C. on Feb. 15, the White House said. (Kobi Gideon/AP) 
Netanyahu, who for years held a contentious relationship with former President Barack Obama, was emboldened by Trump's election and announced plans to build over 6,000 new settlements homes last month. 
Israel approves 2,500 West Bank settler homes 
Earlier Thursday, Netanyahu expressed "great pain" over the removal of Amona, an outpost that Israel's Supreme Court recently concluded was built illegally on private Palestinian two decades ago. Palestinian protestors stand facing the Israeli settlement of Qadumim during clashes with Israeli security forces following a demonstration. (JAAFAR ASHTIYEH/AFP/Getty Images) 
In response to the removal, Netanyahu pledged to initiate construction of 2,000 new homes in the West Bank "as soon as possible." 
"We all understand the depth of the pain and therefore we will establish a new settlement on state land," Netanyahu said at a press conference. "Already yesterday I formed a team that will determine the settlement location and get everything ready." 
With News Wire Services
